awd_titl_txt: EAGER: An Evolutionary-Inspired Approach for Moving Target Defenses
awd_abstract_narration:
Computers are often deployed in a deterministic fashion, even across unrelated infrastructures, in order to simplify their life-cycle management. Unfortunately a predictable environment also aids attackers since a small set of exploits can be applied across a large number of similarly configured computers. A Moving Target (MT) strategy can be used to address this problem by deploying less deterministic and homogenous systems. For example intermittently changing a system's configuration (operating systems and/or applications) can create a MT defense that limits the usefulness of an attacker's knowledge; however, these alternative configurations must be functional and secure, while diverse.

This research explores a new Moving Target (MT) defense strategy that leverages Genetic Algorithms (GAs) to manage computer configurations. The technique discovers better solutions (configurations) by mimicking processes found in nature. Computer configurations are modeled as chromosomes, where configuration parameters, or settings, are individual chromosome traits. The GA proceeds by applying a series of selection, crossover, and mutation processes to discover  new chromosomes from a pool. Since the system constantly evolves, it is designed to cope with new vulnerabilities or functionalities that can be potentially introduced over time.

An important objective is the development a prototype MT system that can provide a better understanding of the performance of evolutionary-based configuration management. Results will be of interest to researchers and practitioners since the approach is applicable to a variety of configurations. Furthermore this project will also introduce undergraduates to academic research in the area of computer security and system management.

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of this  project is a  Genetic Algorithm based Moving Target (GAMT) defense system where computer configurations (operating system and/or applications) automatically evolve to be more secure and diverse. Computer configurations are modeled as chromosomes, where configuration parameters, or settings, are individual chromosome traits. For example consider the Apache server configurations, which have a complex of set interdependent parameters that must be correctly managed to ensure functionality and security. The GA proceeds by applying a series of selection, crossover, and mutation processes to discover a new chromosome from an existing pool of chromosomes. The new chromosome is assessed using automated tests to ensure functionality and to quantify security. If acceptable, the chromosome is added to a pool which serves as the source of configurations to be automatically implemented by the host at different points in time. Therefore the objective of the GA is to have the chromosome pool (set of enactable configurations) constantly evolve in response to any changing conditions and can become diverse and more secure over time. Furthermore since the system constantly evolves, it is designed to cope with new vulnerabilities or system functionalities.

 

The GA Moving Target (GAMT) approach has refined the GA to better manage configurations, generating configurations (for testing) to help understand the limits of the GA, and measuring diversity. These tasks were then added to the GAMT.  As well, an extensive study has undertaken to determine effective techniques to measure chromosome security when a large number of configurations are modeled, and the configurations are potentially under different types of attacks over time.

 

During the extended grant period, the focus was to examine chains of configurations that lead to an insecurity.  There exist separate configuration parameters, that individually do not lead to an insecurity, but when taken together allow an insecure situation.  The goal to have  interesting configuration dependencies discovered by the evolutionary approach (GAMT).
